pr_title: [#9946] Add additional fields for Student Search Migration

timeline.message:
Fix str equality

Fix str equality

timeline.bodyText:
Why do we need institute  and courseIdToInstructorGoogleIdMap?
Again, we have already violated the principle that StudentData.java should only contains information related to a student. institute is technically yes but definitely not courseIdToInstructorGoogleIdMap/
timeline.author: xpdavid

replies.bodyText: Yea my bad, we could just make a call on front end side for all courses. For institute however, I could not find any endpoint through which I could get institute, so i included it here. wdyt?
replies.author: hcwong

replies.bodyText: Why do we need institute? The currently implementation is a bit expensive especially for the for each loop.
replies.author: xpdavid

replies.bodyText: I included it to match the current object being returned by the Admin endpoint, which has institute in it
replies.author: hcwong

replies.bodyText: I think you should not consider "what the old endpoint will return". Rather, you should try to answer "whether I need the data or not".
replies.author: xpdavid

replies.bodyText: Cool, that actually makes things easier for the search service 😆
replies.author: hcwong

replies.bodyText: Hmm, sorry, will include institute because it is being used on admin-search-page.html, but will cut whatever i can cut from the new endpoint
replies.author: hcwong

timeline.bodyText:
I think we might want to improve this?
Iterating the whole array to find the corresponding element is not really attracting.
timeline.author: xpdavid

replies.bodyText:
Hey Xiao Pu,
I think there were two alternatives I considered when doing this.
First, is to put the key generation inside the constructor. However, this will place the burden of hiding the key on the developer. Since Teammates has many contributors, I opted not to do this as people who use StudentsData in the future may not be aware of this and thus send the key.
Yea, theres a runtime issue, but I think this should be fine as its Java, so it should run faster and because the performance bottleneck is at the frontend side.
What do you think?
replies.author: hcwong
xpdavid

replies.bodyText: Hey Xiao Pu, that is a fair point about the two places thing. Will change 👍
replies.author: hcwong

timeline.bodyText: Since it doesn't make sense to have a StudentsData object with no students, do you think we can make this constructor take List<StudentData> as an argument? Then we can leave students as final and remove the setter.
timeline.author: dvrylc

replies.bodyText: There's an issue of type erasure though (cue 2103 flashbacks), cos the other constructor takes in List<StudentAttributes>. I could make these constructor instantiate an empty List<StudentData> though, just in case
replies.author: hcwong

replies.bodyText: Oh right I didn't consider that, let's just stick with this but maybe add a comment to explain/warn future devs? An empty list doesn't really solve the problem either 😞
replies.author: dvrylc

timeline.bodyText: Instead of creating the StudentsData > setting the students > getting the students > setting the institute data, could we do all the data manipulation (setting key and institute) on the studentDataList first? Then once we have a finalized studentDataList, pass it to the StudentsData constructor as mentioned above.
timeline.author: dvrylc
